items.content_html:
Summary

In Chrome 126, the behavior of the GPUQueue.submit() method has been updated to be correct as per spec â€” the referenced command buffers must be unique.

This PR adds a data point for this update.

See https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-webgpu-126#submitted_command_buffers_must_be_unique for the information source.

Test results and supporting details

Related issues

project issue: mdn/content#36344
items.title: Add data point about GPUQueue.submit() unique command buffers

items.content_html:
Summary

Safari (and older versions of Blink-based browsers) are supporting box-decoration-break only for inline elements. While a note was already present, this is not reported as being a partial implementation in such case.

Test results and supporting details

https://web.dev/blog/web-platform-10-2024?hl=en#full_box-decoration-break_support

Related issues
items.title: Mark box-decoration-break as partial when only inline works

items.content_html:
Summary

Reading the doc, I was under the impression, that Firefox on Android and Fennec support video textures, but that turned to be not the case. This was reported in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1884282 and is unresolved for quite some time. This PR adds a compatibility note with texImage2D and texSubImage2D to indicate textures from video elements not being supported.

Test results and supporting details

Related issues
items.title: Add compatibility note addressing teximage2D not supporting video elements on firefox for android and fennec

items.content_html: This PR is a small subset of #24093 that uses purely ranges to eliminate non-real values from this file. See #24093 for supporting evidence on feature support.
items.title: Replace nonreal values for optional_permissions with ranges

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR adds compat data for all the additional features defined in the WebGPU spec that can be enabled for a GPUDevice.

It also adds data for API features that are available when certain additional features are enabled.

Data sources:

  • clip-distances: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5141929256550400
  • timestamp-queries: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-webgpu-121#timestamp_queries_in_compute_and_render_passes
  • dual-source-blending: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-webgpu-130#dual_source_blending
  • float32-filterable: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-webgpu-119#filterable_32-bit_float_textures
  • shader-f16: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-webgpu-120#support_for_16-bit_floating-point_values_in_wgsl
  • float32-blendable: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5173655901044736

For features that I couldn't find specific data on, I am currently just assuming that they were supported at the same time as WebGPU first shipped (Chrome 113, Chrome Android 121), but this may not be true for all of them. I will check these with the Chrome eng folk, going forward.

Test results and supporting details

Related issues

Part of the Bring MDN up-to-date with WebGPU updates project.
items.title: Add support for WebGPU supported features

items.content_html:
Summary

Google has moved to a different issue tracker, namely from Monorail to the Google Issue Tracker, and this means all prior bugs have received a new id.

This adds a link lint check, for which the linter needed to be made async, and fixes all issues.

Test results and supporting details

Related issues
items.title: Migrate Google issue IDs

items.content_html:
Summary

Add partial_implementation: true for the implementation of the Notification API in Safari iOS.

The reason for this is that those BCD keys already have a note saying: "Notifications are supported in web apps saved to the home screen".
Requiring the site to be installed as an app on the iOS home screen is a big requirement for users, which means that most users will not see website notifications.

The right thing to do, to me, is to add the partial_implementation: true flag to make it more visible that the feature doesn't work in Safari for iOS, like it does in other browsers.
items.title: Mark iOS Safari's implementation of Notification partial because it requires the site to be saved to the home screen

items.content_html:
I tried to generate web-features locally using WebViews as part of the browser set.

I found that there were a few keys that webview_ios wasn't set for.

As far as I can see, in each of the places it was missing it was set as mirror for other keys for those elements.
items.title: Add missing statements for webview_ios

items.title: cookies.get orders cookies according to RFC-6265

items.content_html:
This PR adds the missing flow member of the display CSS property. The data comes from the mdn-bcd-collector project (v10.12.3).

Check out the collector's guide on how to review this PR.

Tests Used: https://mdn-bcd-collector.gooborg.com/tests/css/properties/display/flow
items.title: Add missing css.properties.display.flow feature

items.content_html:
This PR updates and corrects version values for Chromium (Chrome, Opera, Samsung Internet, WebView Android) for the extension Web Extensions interface. The data comes from a commit in the browser's source code, mapped to a version number using available tooling or via the commit timestamp.
